entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 27 at 8:47PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Sanford affecting Seminole County.
.The Saint Johns River at Sanford is forecast to continue a slow decline through Minor Flood Stage over the next 5 days. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River at Sanford should remain prepared for prolonged minor flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Sanford...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Monday morning at 1145 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Sanford.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 6.5 feet, Water enters a few lower lying homes in the Stone Island and Stillbrook subdivisions. The road into Stone Island becomes impassable. Water rises onto low lying property near Sanford. Parks and docks are flooded near Lake Monroe.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 6.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 4.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:30 PM EDT Sunday was 6.8 feet. - Forecast...The river, which is currently around 6.7 feet, will continue a gradual decline through Minor Flood Stage this weekend into next week. - Flood stage is 5.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Seminole, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 27 at 8:44PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Above Lake Harney affecting Seminole County.
.The Saint Johns River above Lake Harney near Geneva is forecast to continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage early this week then lower to Minor flood stage later this week. Residents and interests along the St. Johns River near Lake Harney will continue to experience prolonged flood impacts.
For the St. Johns River...including Above Lake Harney...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Monday morning at 1130 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Above Lake Harney.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.3 feet, Many secondary roads are flooded near Lake Harney. Flooding in the Hatbill Road area near Loughman Lake.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 9.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 6.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:30 PM EDT Sunday was 9.3 feet. - Forecast...The river, which is currently around 9.2 feet, will continue a gradual decline through Moderate Flood Stage then lower to Minor Flood stage this week. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Seminole, FL

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 7:34PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
A very dry air mass and breezy conditions will combine with dead and dry fuels such as grass, leaves, and twigs to create the potential for uncontrolled fire spread across the southern half of New Hampshire on Monday. Relative humidity values will decrease to low levels of 20-25%. Winds will be lighter than Sunday, generally around 10 mph.
Extra caution should be taken to prevent wildfires. Always consult with fire officials before engaging in any open burning activities and comply with all applicable laws and regulations. Never leave an open fire unattended and always extinguish campfires completely before leaving.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Grafton; Southern Carroll; Sullivan; Merrimack; Belknap; Strafford; Cheshire; Eastern Hillsborough; Interior Rockingham; Coastal Rockingham; Western And Central Hillsborough

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 6:51PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
There continues to be an increased risk of fire spread through Monday. Relative humidity values Monday afternoon will drop to 20 to 30 percent across much of the area. Winds will remain light from the east to northeast around 5 to 10 mph, turning southeast in the afternoon with temperatures in the low to mid 60s and abundant sunshine. Vegetation remains very dry and could potentially become fuel for fires. These conditions will support the spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control.
Outdoor burning is strongly discouraged. Be sure to properly extinguish or dispose of any potential ignition sources, including smoking materials such as cigarette butts. Refer to your state's forest fire management agency for more information on burn restrictions in your local area.
Relative humidity values recover to around 40 to 50 percent on Tuesday with southerly winds around 5 to 10 mph with gusts up to 15 mph. Regardless, burn restrictions may still be in place given the very dry conditions and lack of any recent rainfall. Refer to your state or local fire officials for more information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: New Castle; Kent; Inland Sussex; Delaware Beaches; Kent; Queen Anne's; Talbot; Caroline; Sussex; Warren; Morris; Hunterdon; Somerset; Middlesex; Western Monmouth; Eastern Monmouth; Mercer; Salem; Gloucester; Camden; Northwestern Burlington; Ocean; Cumberland; Atlantic; Cape May; Atlantic Coastal Cape May; Coastal Atlantic; Coastal Ocean; Southeastern Burlington; Carbon; Monroe; Berks; Lehigh; Northampton; Delaware; Philadelphia; Western Chester; Eastern Chester; Western Montgomery; Eastern Montgomery; Upper Bucks; Lower Bucks

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 27 at 1:35PM AKDT until October 28 at 6:00AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Mixed precipitation, including freezing rain, snow, and rain expected. Total ice accumulations of a glaze to a few hundredths of an inch. Snow accumulations of up to 2 inches.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay from Dillingham north, including Koliganek and New Stuyahok.
* WHEN...From 7 PM Sunday to 6 AM AKDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Precipitation is expected to begin this evening as snow or a wintry mix before transitioning to a period of freezing rain overnight tonight into early Monday morning. In general, precipitation is expected to turn to all rain Monday morning. There continues to be some uncertainty as to exactly when the transition from freezing rain to rain will occur. If cold air holds on longer, expect ice totals closer to a few hundredths of an inch. Should temperatures warm faster, expect only a glaze of ice.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bristol Bay

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 1:34PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A Bering Sea front will move ashore of Southwest Alaska coast this afternoon. Snow will spread from west to east across the Lower Kuskokwim Valley starting this evening and pick up in intensity overnight tonight. Snow will become lighter from west to east Monday morning while moderate snow will persist for locations near the Western Alaska Range. In general, expect most snow to fall from Crooked Creek southeastward to Lime Village where 3 to 6 inches are possible. Higher amounts are likely near the Western Alaska Range.
There is some mixed precipitation/freezing rain potential across the western most areas of the region, including Aniak with warmer air trying to nudge in aloft. The best chance at a period of mixed precipitation for western areas would be this evening before cooler air aloft works back in late tonight into Monday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kuskokwim Valley

cap:parameter.value: MODERATE SNOW LIKELY ACROSS THE LOWER KUSKOKWIM VALLEY THIS EVENING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 27 at 1:24PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect from 2 AM Monday to 9AM Tuesday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
For the latest air quality forecasts and information, visit the website at aqmd.gov.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coachella Valley

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 12:22PM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
The potential for snow for the Northern panhandle as well as the Icy Strait corridor including Juneau is looking less likely. Winds look to switch to the south earlier than previously thought as the low is expected to be stronger. Besides the winds switching around earlier, the temperatures aloft are also expected to increase which will hinder the any potential for accumulating snow for locations at lower elevations. With the warmer temperatures and earlier switch in wind directions, rain will be the more dominant precipitation type. A rain snow mix is possible for the northern Lynn Canal area but accumulations look to be minimal to none.
As always, the latest forecast information can be found at www.weather.gov/Juneau.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 27 at 8:34AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Imperial County APCD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect from 11 AM Monday through Monday evening.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Imperial County Southwest; Imperial County West; Imperial Valley

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 27 at 8:07AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has issued a PM-10 High Pollution Advisory for the Yuma area on Monday.
An episode of strong and gusty winds is forecast to generate widespread blowing dust that may result in local PM-10 concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Coarse particulate matter - also known as PM-10 - is an air contaminant that can aggravate heart and lung disease conditions, especially in older adults, children, and those with asthma. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
Consolidate your travel, stabilize loose soils, slow down or avoid travel on dirt roads, reduce or eliminate fireplace use, and avoid using gas-powered lawn equipment.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/yuma or call 602-771-2300.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma

cap:parameter.value: PM-10 HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR THE YUMA AREA MONDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 5:22AM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
A Bering Sea front will move ashore of Southwest Alaska this afternoon. Snow will spread from west to east across the Lower Kuskokwim Valley starting this evening and pick up in intensity tonight. Snow will become lighter from west to east Monday morning while moderate snow will persist for locations near the Western Alaska Range. In general, expect most snow to fall from Crooked Creek southeastward to Lime Village where 3 to 6 inches are possible. Higher amounts are likely near the Western Alaska Range.
There is some mixed precipitation/freezing rain potential across the western most areas of the region, including Aniak with warmer air trying to nudge in aloft. The best chance at a period of mixed precipitation for western areas would be this evening before cooler air aloft works back in late tonight into Monday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kuskokwim Valley

cap:parameter.value: MODERATE SNOW LIKELY ACROSS THE LOWER KUSKOKWIM VALLEY THIS EVENING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued October 27 at 2:29AM HST until October 27 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH FOR ALL HAWAIIAN ISLANDS THROUGH THIS AFTERNOON...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...All the main Hawaiian islands.
* WHEN...Through this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - An upper low will move over the islands today and result in continued unstable conditions within a very moist atmosphere. There will be enough instability to produce periodic showers. Rain could become locally heavy, with a chance for isolated thunderstorms, particularly over windward areas. Periods of heavy showers over already saturated grounds could quickly lead to runoff and flash flooding issues. Water levels in elevated streams could rise rapidly with additional heavy rain.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 3:41AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A low pressure system and associated frontal boundary will approach the west coast Sunday evening into Monday. Snow and easterly winds will increase across the area and there will be periods of blowing snow and low visibilities of one mile or less at times Sunday evening into Monday morning. Snow showers will continue on Monday but winds will begin to weaken by Monday evening.
Stay up to date with the latest forecast by visiting our webpage, weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 27 at 3:23AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A weather system moving across Alaska will bring heavy snowfall to the southeastern Interior beginning Monday night and lasting through Wednesday afternoon. Snowfall for the 2-day period expected to be around 5 to 10 inches, with the heaviest accumulations expected between Dot Lake and Northway.
Stay up to date with the latest forecast by visiting our webpage, weather.gov/afg.
